etymologies: late Middle English: of unknown origin

definitions: a long-bodied chiefly marine fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, a prominent dorsal fin, and toothlike scales. Most sharks are predatory, although the largest kinds feed on plankton, and some can grow to a large size.

notes.text: Several orders (or superorders) of the subclass Elasmobranchii: many families

shortDefinitions: long-bodied marine fish with prominent dorsal fin

definitions: a small Southeast Asian freshwater fish with a tail resembling that of a shark, popular in aquaria.

notes.text: Two species in the family Cyprinidae: the small red-tailed black shark (Labeo bicolor), and the larger black shark (Morulius chrysophekadion)

definitions: a light grayish-brown European moth, the male of which has pale silvery hind wings.

notes.text: Genus Cucullia, family Noctuidae: several species, including C. umbratica

etymologies: late 16th century: perhaps from German Schurke ‘worthless rogue’, influenced by shark

definitions: a person who unscrupulously exploits or swindles others

examples.text: property sharks want to develop 200 acres around the site
Coleby was a shark, not the sort of man to pay more when he could pay less

shortDefinitions: person who unscrupulously exploits or swindles others

definitions: an expert in a specified field
